DOCNAME: CASE OF ASSOCIATED SOCIETY OF LOCOMOTIVE ENGINEERS AND FIREMEN (ASLEF) v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (non-exhaustion);Violation of Art. 11;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a trade union , representing mainly train drivers on GPE railways . Founded in DATE , it has CARDINAL members and most train drivers are members of ORG . It is an independent trade union . The various companies on the GPE rail network do not operate a “ closed shop ” and railway workers , including drivers , are free to join ORG or other unions or not to join a union at all .

CARDINAL . Its Rules provide that its objects include , as well as regulating relations between workers and employers and protecting the welfare of members and the industry , that it “ assist in the furtherance of the labour movement generally towards a NORP society ( Rule CARDINAL.CARDINAL(vii ) and to “ promote and develop and enact positive policies in regard to equality of treatment in our industries and ORG regardless of sex , sexual orientation , marital status , religion , creed , colour , race or ethnic origin ” ( Rule CARDINAL.CARDINAL(viii ) ) .

CARDINAL . In DATE the Annual Assembly of Delegates(“AAD ” ) of ORG , its governing body , resolved , pursuant to rule PERSON ) of ORG rules , that " this ORG being concerned with the rise of ORG activists and groups instruct ORG to campaign vigorously to expose the obnoxious policies of political parties such as ORG . "

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , a Mr PERSON ( a member of the far - right , lawful , ORG ( ' BNP ' ) , previously known as ORG ) applied for membership in ORG and was accepted . In DATE Mr PERSON stood as a candidate in the local elections in GPE for the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE an ORG trade union officer sent a report to the General Secretary concerning PERSON , attaching information that PERSON was an activist in the ORG , had handed out anti - NORP leaflets dressed as a priest and that in DATE he had stood as a candidate for the ORG in GPE . The report included an article written by PERSON ( the ORG magazine ) and a fax from ORG stating that Mr PERSON had seriously harassed PERCENT pamphleteers , including taking pictures of them , taking their car numbers , making throat - cutting gestures and following CARDINAL woman in his car and visibly noting her home address , which matters had been reported to the police .

CARDINAL . On DATE , an ORG meeting of ORG voted unanimously to expel PERSON , who was so informed by a letter of DATE , which stated that his membership of the ORG was incompatible with membership with ORG , that he was likely to bring the union into disrepute and that he was against the objects of the union .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON appealed against the expulsion and was informed that a hearing would take place on DATE . On DATE , he stated that he would not attend . On DATE , ORG of ORG met and rejected his appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG resolved " that membership of the ORG or similar NORP organisation is incompatible with being a member of ORG as determined under Rule CARDINAL . Therefore any members of ORG who are members of , or apply for membership , of ORG shall be removed from membership or refused membership . " The rules were changed accordingly to read :
Rule CARDINAL ) :

“ No person shall be admitted into membership of ORG if by choice they are members of , supporters of , or sympathisers with , organisations which are diametrically opposed to the objects of the union , such as a fascist organisation . ”

CARDINAL . In the meantime , PERSON had brought proceedings in ORG ) in respect of his expulsion , on the basis of section CARDINAL ORG and ORG DATE ( ' section CARDINAL ' ) , which prohibits trade unions from excluding a person or expelling a member wholly or to any extent on the ground that the individual is or was a member of a political party . The ORG found in favour of PERSON on DATE . The applicant appealed to ORG ( ' ORG ' ) , which on DATE found that the first ORG had fallen into serious errors of law , quashed the decision and remitted it to a second ET .

CARDINAL . The ORG considered that it could construe section CARDINAL without the need to resort to LAW . It noted the parties ' submissions , including the applicant 's reliance on the decision in PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , ORG . DATE , PERSON , p. CARDINAL ) and continued :

“ As we have indicated [ counsel for the applicant ] accepts that we are not in a position to grant a declaration of incompatibility , on the one hand ... But it is also clear to us that the very existence of competing claims under LAW ( albeit that it would seem to us , on the authorities , that , absent a case of prejudice to livelihood , in this case [ the applicant 's ] right of negative association for the Union and its members would seem likely to override the asserted right of association of [ Mr PERSON ] ) renders it more appropriate for us to seek to resolve the construction of the statute without reference to those competing rights . [ Counsel for the applicant ] , while reserving his position , does not dissent from that course , and [ counsel for Mr PERSON ] said that he understood , and indeed accepted that it was thereby being assumed in [ his favour ] that there is at least arguable an LAW right , such as he asserts . ”

CARDINAL . The ORG 's conclusion on the meaning of section CARDINAL was that a union could rely as a legitimate ground for expulsion on the conduct of the expelled member so long as that conduct was not the fact of being a member of a political party . It found that a union could not rely on conduct which was a “ necessary act for the purpose of being or continuing to be a member ” ( at paragraph CARDINAL of its judgment ) . It specifically rejected the submission advanced by the applicant that included in the concept of membership ( and thus amounting to conduct on which the union was not permitted to rely ) was conduct as a member , or in the capacity as a member , of a political party ( paragraph CARDINAL of the ORG judgment ) .

CARDINAL . A second ET again upheld Mr PERSON 's complaint by way of decision promulgated on DATE . It rejected the applicant 's defence that Mr PERSON 's expulsion was entirely attributable to his conduct ( apart from the fact of membership of the ORG ) for the purpose of section CARDINAL , holding that the expulsion was “ primarily because of his membership of the BNP ” ( paragraph CARDINAL of its judgment ) .
CARDINAL . The applicant did not appeal to the ORG against the second decision of the ET .

CARDINAL . In consequence of the second decision of the ET , the applicant has been obliged to re - admit PERSON to the membership of the Union . It is in breach of its own Rules in so doing . Had the applicant not re - admitted Mr PERSON , it would have been liable to pay him compensation in such sum as the ET considered just and equitable ( subject to a statutory minimum of , currently , just over CARDINAL,CARDINAL euros ( ORG ) , with no upper limit ) . Even though it has re - admitted PERSON , the applicant remains exposed to an application from PERSON for compensation in such sum as the ORG considers just and equitable but subject to an upper limit of around ORG CARDINAL . It does not appear that PERSON has made any such application .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of ORG DATE reads in relevant part :
( CARDINAL ) An individual shall not be excluded or expelled from a trade union unless the exclusion or expulsion is permitted by this section .
( CARDINAL ) The exclusion or expulsion of an individual from a trade union is permitted by this section if ( and only if ) –
( d ) the exclusion or expulsion is entirely attributable to his conduct .
( CARDINAL ) For purposes of subsection ORG ) ' conduct , ' in relation to an individual , does not include –
( a ) his being or ceasing to be , or having been or ceased to be -
( iii ) a member of a political party , or ... ”
CARDINAL . Subsequent to the decision of the second ET in PERSON case , section CARDINAL was amended ( with effect from DATE ) to read as follows ( again in material part only ) :
“ ( CARDINAL ) An individual shall not be excluded or expelled from a trade union unless the exclusion or expulsion is permitted by this section .
( CARDINAL ) The exclusion or expulsion of an individual from a trade union is permitted by this section if ( and only if ) –
( d ) the exclusion or expulsion is entirely attributable to conduct of his ( other than excluded conduct ) and the conduct to which it is wholly or mainly attributable is not protected conduct .
( CARDINAL ) For purposes of subsection ( CARDINAL ) “ excluded conduct , ” in relation to an individual , means –
( a ) conduct which consists in his being or ceasing to , or having been or ceased to be , a member of another trade union
( b ) conduct which consists in his being or ceasing to be , or having been or ceased to be , employed by a particular employer or at a particular place , or

( c ) conduct to which LAW ( conduct for which an employer may not be disciplined by a union ) applies or would apply if the references in that section to the trade union which is relevant for the purposes of that section were references to any trade union .

( CARDINAL ) For the purposes of subsection ( CARDINAL ) “ protected conduct ” is conduct which consists in the individual 's being or ceasing to be , or having been or ceased to be , a member of a political party .
( CARDINALB ) conduct which consists of activities undertaken by an individual as a member of a political party is not conduct falling within subsection ( CARDINAL ) . .. ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) provides that “ ' conduct ' includes statements , acts and omissions . ”
CARDINAL . DATE of NORP Social Charter DATE provides for the following “ right to organise ” :

“ With a view to ensuring or promoting the freedom of workers and employers to form local , national or international organisations for the protection of their economic and social interests and to join those organisations , the Contracting Parties undertake that national law shall not be such as to impair , nor shall it be so applied as to impair , this freedom . The extent to which the guarantees provided for in this Article shall apply to the police shall be determined by national laws or regulations . The principle governing the application to the members of the armed forces of these guarantees and the extent to which they shall apply to persons in this category shall equally be determined by national laws or regulations . ”

CARDINAL . In that context , ORG ( formerly ORG ” , which is the supervisory body of the European Social Charter CARDINAL has given consideration on numerous occasions to sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the DATE Act . Concern with the interference by section CARDINAL in the right of trade unions to fix their own rules and choose their own members was expressed by ORG , p. CARDINAL ; Conclusions XV-CARDINAL p. CARDINAL ; and in DATE , Conclusions PERSON , p. CARDINAL where it held :

“ Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act limits the grounds on which a person may be refused admission to or expelled from a trade union to such an extent as to constitute an excessive restriction on the rights of a trade union to determine its conditions for membership and goes beyond what is required to secure the individual right to join a trade union .... ORG concludes that , in light of the provisions of ORG ) DATE referred to above ( sections DATE , CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) the situation in GPE is not in conformity with LAW ”

CARDINAL . In Conclusions XVII-CARDINAL ( DATE ) it again concluded that GPE was not in conformity with LAW as section CARDINAL constituted an excessive restriction on trade unions ' right to determine their membership conditions .
